A series of metal oxides Mn8Ni2Ce a O x (a = 0–1.5) catalysts were prepared by hydrothermal co-precipitation to investigate the effect of Ce doping on manganese-based oxides for toluene catalytic combustion reaction. Activity evaluations show that Mn8Ni2CeO x (a = 1) catalyst exhibits highly efficient toluene oxidation activity and high yield to CO2 production. Durability tests reveal that it has remarkably superior water resistance ability and promising potential for practical application. Various characterizations were conducted to explore possible structure-activity correlations. Results show that Ce introduction could construct the strong Ce-Mn interactions, generate more oxygen vacancies, facilitate lattice oxygen mobility, and increase the content of surface active oxygen. These changes efficiently utilize active oxygen species and accelerate the deep oxidation of benzyl alcohol/benzoate intermediates, therefore render activity advantages. Otherwise, Ce doping can effectively maintain the catalyst's structural stability while simultaneously inhibiting H2O adsorption on the catalyst surface under humid atmosphere, thus being conducive to the outstanding durability and water resistance ability. Graphical abstract Mn8Ni2CeaOx (a = 0–1.5) synthesized via hydrothermal co-precipitation strategy exhibits highly efficient catalytic activity as well as superior water resistance. Image, graphical abstract Keywords Toluene Mn-Ni oxides Ce doping Catalytic oxidation Water resistance Data availability No data was used for the research described in the article. Introduction Toluene is emitted in industrial production in large quantities including heat treatment, printing and dyeing, and spraying [1]. The purification methods of toluene include biodegradation [2], photocatalytic degradation [3], plasma degradation [4], etc. among which the catalytic combustion method is widely considered to exhibit broad application prospects due to its advantages of low energy consumption, high efficiency, and no secondary pollution [5]. The key to efficient catalytic combustion technology depends on the development of high-performance oxidation catalyst [6]. Especially considering that the composition of gas is complex with the existence of H2O, methane, propane and other refractory substances [7] in the actual working conditions for VOCs purification, therefore, in addition to catalytic activity, the characteristics of thermal stability and water resistance are also very important for effective catalytic combustion of VOCs. Generally, noble metal-based materials such as Pt [8], Ru [9], and Pd [10] are recognized to show the best activity performance in low-temperature catalytic combustion [11], but their expensive cost and poor thermal stability restrict their wide application [12]. In recent decades, non-precious metal-based materials, such as Cu [13], Mn [14,15], Co [16,17], and Ce [18], have attracted more and more attention due to their variable oxidation states, good oxygen storage capacity and oxygen mobility. Among various metal oxides studied, Mn oxides are one of the most widely reported candidates because of their easy availability, low cost and high oxidation ability. Wang et al. [19] prepared Mn2Co catalyst by the agar-gel method and found it could convert 90.00% toluene to CO2 at 238.0 ℃ along with excellent water resistance under 20 vol.% H2O. Xiaobo and Zhihong [20] found Cu1Mn1 catalyst had excellent catalytic activity of toluene. Based on the results of XPS and other characterization methods, it is attributed to the synergistic effect of Mn4+ and Cu2+ reducing the combustion temperature of the catalyst. More importantly, doping metal oxides with secondary transition metals can adjust the catalysts’ microstructures (such as forming solid solutions) and improve active centers distribution on the catalysts’ surface, which could influence the catalytic activity through the interaction between metals [19,21,22]. Many studies have found that the doping of Ce can improve the catalytic behaviors of the dual metal oxides catalysts. For example, Lu et al. [23] prepared CuOCeO2 catalysts and found that the electron transfer between Cu and Ce enhanced redox and oxygen mobility. Ismail et al. [24] synthesized a series of Co x Ce1- x O2-δ (x = 0.05–0.6) oxides and found that Co0.2Ce0.8O2-δ exhibits better catalytic activity for toluene than pure Co3O4 and CeO2 owing to the formation of solid solutions of Co and Ce oxides [18]. Our preview study reported that Mn8Ni2O x composite oxide catalyst showed excellent catalytic efficiency for low temperature toluene combustion. Unfortunately, its water resistance was quite inferior, as toluene conversion dropped to about 40.0% after adding 5 vol.% H2O [25]. Herein, we propose that doping Ce into Mn8Ni2O x composite oxide would be a promising way to improve the catalyst's water resistance ability. In the current work, Mn8Ni2Ce a Ox (a = 0–1.5) composite oxide catalysts were prepared by hydrothermal co-precipitation method. Toluene was also selected as the probe molecule to evaluate the catalytic activity. Affection of factors including doping amount, calcination temperature, and reaction space velocity were examined, and the durability and water resistance ability were also tested. The influence of Ce doping on the physio-chemical properties of the Mn8Ni2Ce a O x catalyst were validated via systematical characterizations and the intermediate products of toluene adsorption and oxidation were analyzed by in situ infrared spectroscopy (in situ FTIR). The scope of this work is to report highly efficient Mn8Ni2Ce a Ox catalysts with superior water resistance, and to explore the effect of Ce doping on catalytic performance over Mn based oxides catalysts from the aspect of active species evolution and possible reaction mechanism. Experimental Catalysts preparation Mn8Ni2Ce a Ox catalysts were prepared by redox co-precipitation method. Briefly, 18.60 mL of 50% Mn(NO3)2 solution (0.08 mol), 0.02 mol Ni(NO3)2•6H2O, and 0.015 mol Ce(NO3)3•6H2O were dissolved in distilled water with the total cation concentration at 1.0 mol/L. The above solution and NaOH (1.0 mol/L) solution were added dropwise to 115 mL of Na2CO3 (0.05 mol/L) solution at the same time to stabilize pH at about 10 and kept stirring for 0.5 h. The obtained precipitate was placed in a Teflon-lined crystallization kettle and hold on statically at 100.0 ℃ for 24 h hydrothermal reaction. The hydrothermal product was then washed with water/ethanol for 5 times, and dried at 100 °C. Finally, the obtained precursors were calcined in a muffle furnace at 400.0 ℃ for 4 h to obtain Mn8Ni2Ce1.5O x catalyst. The other Mn8Ni2Ce a O x (a = 0, 0.25, 0.5, 0.75, 1, 1.25) catalysts were prepared according to the above same method via changing Ce(NO3)3•6H2O amount. Catalyst characterization X-ray diffraction (XRD) was performed on a Rigaku-Dmax-rA diffractometer (Rigaku Corporation) equipped with Cu Kα radiation operated at 40 kV and 30 mA. The XRD data were generally collected from 10 to 70° with a scanning rate of 10 °/min with a step size of 0.02 ° N2 adsorption/desorption was performed on a Kubo-x-1000 analyzer (Beijing Biode Co., Ltd.) at −196.0 ℃. The samples were pre-degassed at 200.0 ℃ for 2 h under vacuum conditions. Scanning electron microscopy (SEM) was performed on a Hitachi S-4800 microscope (Hitachi Corporation) at 5 kV. Thermogravimetric Analysis (TG) was performed with a Q600SDT thermal differential analyzer (TA Company). The samples were heated from 20.0 ℃ to 850.0 ℃ with a 10.0 ℃/min heating rate under N2 atmosphere. Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (FTIR) was performed with a TENSOR 27 infrared spectrometer (Bruker Company) equipped with DTGS detector. 20 mg samples were baked using IR lights and then pressed before tests. The IR spectra were recorded at RT by accumulating 16 scans at a resolution of 8 cm−1. Hydrogen temperature-programmed reduction (H2-TPR) was carried out by the FINESORB-3010 chemical adsorption instrument (FINETEC Corporation). Before the test, 100 mg sample was pretreated in Ar atmosphere for 20 min at 20.0 ℃ and then purged with 10% H2/Ar mixed gas. After the baseline was stable, the TPR test was carried out by recording TCD signal change while ramping the temperature from 20.0 ℃ to 700.0 ℃ in speed of 10.0 ℃/min. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) was acquired on a PHI5000 X-ray photoelectron spectrometer (Japan ULVAC-PHI Corporation) equipped with mono-chromated Al Kα radiation. The in-situ Fourier infrared transmission spectroscopy (in-situ FTIR) was performed on an in-situ spectroscopy/high vacuum integrated testing system (Xiamen Tops Instrument Development Co., Ltd.) attached to the TENSOR 27 infrared spectrometer (Bruker Company). First, the reaction chamber was first evacuated to a high vacuum state with the temperature of 300.0 ℃ for 30 min. and the background spectra were recorded at 180.0 ℃, 200.0 ℃, 210.0 ℃, 220.0 ℃, 230.0 ℃, 240.0 ℃, and 250.0 ℃, respectively. During the tests, toluene gas was introduced, and the infrared spectrum was recorded at 0 min, 5 min, 10 min, 20 min, 60 min and 100 min during the adsorption process at 180.0 ℃. After that, the reaction temperature is programmed at 180.0 ℃, 200.0 ℃, 210.0 ℃, 220.0 ℃, 230.0 ℃, and 240.0 ℃. The infrared spectra were recorded at each temperature while simultaneously introducing O2 into the reaction chamber. Catalytic activity tests The catalytic activity evaluations were carried out in a self-built fixed bed reactor. The catalyst was first purged with N2 at 200.0 ℃ for 1 h before testing. The reaction gas contained 1000 ppm toluene and clean air (21.00% O2 and 79.00% N2) and the weight hourly space velocity (WHSV) was maintained at 40,000 mL/(g·h). The VOCs in the activity tests were introduced in the gas mixture using a well-employed “bubbling method”. The toluene liquid was brought into the reactor by purging N2 carrier gas through a saturator kept at 0 °C and the flow rate of the N2 was controlled by a mass flowmeter. During activity tests, the reactor temperature was raised to certain points and then maintained for about 30 min till stable reaction. The outlet gas was analyzed by a GC-9680–5C gas chromatograph (Shanghai Qiyang instruments CO.LTD). The toluene conversion rate, CO2 yield and specific surface area reaction rate of the catalyst at each temperature can be calculated from the initial and outlet toluene concentrations. The formulas are as follows: (1) X t o l u e n e = C in − C out C in × 100 % (2) X C O 2 = C C O 2 7 × C in × 100 % (3) X BET = 0.06 × q C in X t o l u e n e 22.4 × m S BET × 100 % Where, X toluene represents the conversion rate of toluene (%); C in and C out represent the toluene concentration (ppm) in the initial inlet and outlet gas at each temperature point; X CO2 represents the CO2 yield (%); C CO2 represents the CO2 concentration in the outlet gas (ppm); X BET represents the specific surface area reaction rate (mol/(m2·h)); q represents the total flow rate of reaction gas mixture (mL/min); m represents the weight of the catalyst (g); S BET represents the specific surface area of the catalyst (m2/g). Results and discussion Catalytic activity The catalytic activities of the Mn8Ni2Ce a Ox (a = 0–1.5) catalysts were investigated based on catalytic toluene combustion. Fig. 1 shows the toluene conversion along with corresponding CO2 yield of the prepared catalysts at different temperatures. The T90 and T50 (the temperature at which the toluene conversion reaches 90.0% or 50.0% respectively) of each catalyst are listed in Table 1 . As shown, the catalytic activity of Mn8Ni2Ce a O x follows the order of Mn8Ni2CeO x > Mn8Ni2Ce1.25O x > Mn8Ni2Ce1.5O x > Mn8Ni2O x > Mn8Ni2Ce0.75O x > CeO2 > Mn8Ni2Ce0.5O x > Mn8Ni2Ce0.25O x . With increasing Ce content, the catalytic activity first increases and then begins to decrease. Among all the samples, Mn8Ni2CeO x (a = 1) shows the best catalytic activity with T50 and T90 values of 213.3 ℃ and 219.6 ℃, respectively. This indicates that doping an appropriate amount of Ce can be beneficial to the catalytic activity of Mn8Ni2O x . However, when the amount of Ce doping is excessive, the catalytic activity would be severely hindered. Combined with Fig. 1(b), it is found that the CO2 yield of the catalyst is almost proportional to the toluene conversion (X toluene). At higher temperatures (i.e., above 240 ℃ where X toluene reaches 100%), the CO2 yield of Mn8Ni2Ce a O x reaches above 95.0% with carbon balance about 97.0%, and no trace of other HCs-related byproducts was observed by GC during the activity tests, which demonstrates its excellent capability for toluene total oxidation into CO2, making the catalysts quite favorable for reducing secondary hazardous pollutants from incomplete oxidation in practical applications. Adaptability to different reaction space velocity Reaction space velocity is an important factor affecting catalytic performances, especially in the gas-solid heterogeneous reactions. According to the technical specification by the Ministry of Ecology and Environment of China [26], the WHSV of the catalytic combustion device for industrial organic waste gas elimination usually fluctuates in the range of 10,000–40,000 mL/(g·h). To explore the adaptability to different reaction space velocity, the effect of different WHSV on the Mn8Ni2CeO x (a = 1) catalyst with the best catalytic avidity above was examined. As shown in Fig. 2 and Table 2 , the catalytic activity of Mn8Ni2CeO x remains almost unchanged with increasing WHSV, since the T90 of Mn8Ni2CeO x only increases very slightly by less than 1 °C upon raising WHSV from 20,000 mL/(g·h) to 40,000 mL/(g·h). This result indicates that Mn8Ni2CeO x has excellent adaptability to reaction space velocity fluctuation. Affection of calcination temperature The catalyst's thermal stability under high temperatures is another important indicator to measure its comprehensive application potential. According to the above-mentioned technical specification [26], when the catalytic combustion method is used to treat industrial waste gas, the working temperature of the catalyst should be lower than 700.0 ℃, and the temperature of the combined water removal should be higher than 400.0 ℃. As a comparison, the catalytic performance of Mn8Ni2CeO x calcinated under 300.0 ℃ also needs to be tested. Therefore, the different calcination temperature from 300.0 ℃ to 700.0 ℃ with 100.0 ℃ intervals is selected to evaluate the thermal stability of the Mn8Ni2CeO x (a = 1) catalyst. Combining Fig. 3 and Table 2, it is shown that when the calcination temperature is raised from 300.0 ℃ to 400.0 ℃, the T90 of Mn8Ni2CeO x decreases from 217.4 ℃ to 213.3 ℃, which represents better catalytic activity. Then with calcination temperature increasing from 400.0 ℃ to 700.0 ℃, the catalytic performance of Mn8Ni2CeO x is obviously deteriorated. It proves that 400.0 ℃ is the optimum calcination temperature for Mn8Ni2CeO x . Combined with Fig. 8, from 380.0 ℃ hydroxylation and lattice oxygen in catalysts start to release, which could be beneficial to catalytic performance. However, upon calcination at 700.0 ℃, the T90 of Mn8Ni2CeO x catalyst is still less than 240.0 ℃ with CO2 yield above 90.00%, which is approximately equal to that of un-doped Mn8Ni2O x catalyst calcined at 400.0 ℃, This clearly proves that the thermal stability of Mn8Ni2CeO x catalyst is significantly improved by Ce doping. Table 3 compares the catalytic activity of the Mn8Ni2CeO x (a = 1) catalyst with other reported catalysts in the related literature. The reaction rates XBET were also calculated by normalizing to the specific surface areas. It can be seen that the Mn8Ni2CeO x (a = 1) catalyst prepared in our work presents clear activity advantages compared to other non-precious metal composite oxides, and it does not fall too far behind those precious metal catalysts. Considering the obvious high raw-material costs of Pt/Pd based precious metal catalysts, we believe our results could shed new light on the development of cheap and efficient catalysts for toluene catalytic combustion. Durability and water resistance The durability of the Mn8Ni2CeO x (a = 1) catalyst was evaluated by monitoring activity changes at T90 temperatures during the elongated continuous reaction. Fig. 4 (a) shows the toluene conversion of the Mn8Ni2CeO x catalyst can remain above 90.0% during the entire 40 h continuous testing time, which demonstrates remarkable durability of Mn8Ni2CeO x with no obvious deactivation during long-time reaction. Furthermore, the water resistance of the Mn8Ni2CeO x (a = 1) catalyst was also assessed at T90 temperatures by introducing 5 vol% H2O into the reaction atmosphere and the results are shown in Fig. 4(b). For the Mn8Ni2O x catalyst, the toluene conversion gradually decreases to around 40.00% in about 5 h upon H2O introduction. For the Mn8Ni2CeO x catalyst, the toluene conversion almost remains unchanged upon water injection, and it slightly drops to about 85.0% after 15 h reaction in humid conditions. After removing the water vapor from the inlet gas, the X toluene of the Mn8Ni2O x catalyst can quickly recover to 90.00%; while the X toluene of the Mn8Ni2CeO x recovers rapidly to about 99.8%, which is even slightly higher than the X toluene before the water injection. Various researchers [29–31] share common recognition that water vapor is found to act as an inhibitor for toluene deep oxidation, which can be attributed to the competitive adsorption of water and toluene molecules on the active sites, while such inhibition effect could be fully eliminated by removing the water. Our results indicate that the water resistance of Mn8Ni2CeO x catalyst is greatly enhanced by Ce doping. Correlating all the above catalytic performances, it can see that Mn8Ni2CeO x (a = 1) catalyst exhibits with highly efficient toluene oxidation activity, high yield to CO2 production, excellent adaptability to reaction space velocity fluctuation, remarkable thermal stability, and most importantly superior water resistance, which could serve as outstanding candidate catalysts with promising application potential for industrial VOCs purification. XRD analyses Fig. 5 presents the XRD patterns of the prepared Mn8Ni2Ce a O x (a = 0.25–1.5) catalysts. Distinct diffraction peaks can be observed at 18.00°, 28.88°, 32.32° and 45.39°, which corresponds to (101), (112), (103) and (213) planes of tetragonal Mn3O4 phase (JCPDS No.24–0734), respectively; while the diffraction peaks at 37.12°, 42.40° and 66.76° correspond to (100), (101), and (110) planes of hexagonal MnO2 phase (JCPDS No.30–0820), respectively. No characteristic diffraction peaks of Ni species (such as NiO) are observed, which can be attributed either to the low content of the Ni species or the high dispersion of the Ni species in the MnO x matrix to form solid solutions. Such XRD results indicating that Mn8Ni2Ce z O x exhibits characteristic crystalline structure of Mn3O4 and MnO2 at the same time. In addition, no diffraction peaks assigning to the CeO2 phases can be observed, which may be due to the relatively low doping content of Ce, the substitution cations by Ce in the Mn oxides lattice, or that Ce exists in the highly dispersed state. Considering the ionic radius of Ce3+ (0.134 nm) and Ce4+ (0.114 nm) are much larger than that of Ni2+ (0.069 nm), Ni3+ (0.060 nm), Mn3+ (0.064 nm) and Mn4+ (0.053 nm). It's quite likely that Ce tends to disperse in the Mn8Ni2O x [32] matrix rather than substitute Mn/Ni cations in the Mn8Ni2O x lattice. As the Ce content increases, the peak intensity gradually weakens, indicating that the presence of Ce reduces the crystallinity of Mn8Ni2Ce z O x . N2 adsorption/desorption measurements Fig. 6 exhibits the N2 adsorption/desorption isotherms of the prepared Mn8Ni2Ce a O x (a = 0–1.5) catalysts and the corresponding structural parameters are listed in Table 4 . The N2 adsorption/desorption isotherms of Mn8Ni2Ce z O x are similar to the type IV of the H3-type hysteresis ring classified by IUPAC, indicating that the slit-like mesoporous structure formed by the accumulation of sheet-like particles [33]. Combined with the catalytic activity tests above, it is found that the Mn8Ni2Ce1.25O x catalyst exhibits the largest specific surface area and total pore volume, but its catalytic activity is not as good as that of Mn8Ni2CeO x . Although larger specific surface areas are generally beneficial, the above result indicates that the surface areas may not be the sole factor determining the catalytic performances, as the catalytic activity is not linearly proportional to the specific surface area and total pore volume of the catalysts. SEM observations The morphologies of the prepared Mn8Ni2CeO x catalysts were observed by SEM and the obtained SEM images are shown in Fig. 7 . For Mn8Ni2O x without Ce doping (Fig. 7a), it exhibits a regular hexagonal sheet-like structure with spherical particles attached to the surface and certain depressions in the center. For single CeO2 (Fig. 7b), it consists of nanorod-shaped particles with an average particle size around 50–70 nm [24] while MnO x (Fig. 7c) consists of stacked tiny particles. For the Mn8Ni2CeO x catalyst (Fig. 7d), it is composed of unevenly stacked flake-like particles with obviously smaller particle sizes, which is in agreement with the XRD and N2 adsorption/desorption results. No nanorod-like CeO2 particles on the catalyst's surface are observed, indicating that Ce exists in the highly dispersed state in the Mn8Ni2O x [32] matrix and thus providing abundant defects as active sites for toluene oxidation [21]. Thermogravimetric analysis Thermogravimetric tests were also carried out to further explore possible material changes during the water-containing reactions. Fig 8 presents the TG-DTG curves of Mn8Ni2CeO x and Mn8Ni2O x catalysts before/after the water resistance tests. The weight loss in the low temperature range (20–300 °C) be ascribed to the removal of different forms of water adsorbed on the catalyst surface (i.e. physical adsorbed water molecules, and more tightly bonded water molecules such as H2O held on the surface by hydrogen bonding or H2O adsorbed on the surface VO); while the weight loss in the higher temperature range (350.0–800.0 ℃) can be attributed to dehydroxylation and loss of lattice oxygen according to previous studies [34–38]. As shown in Fig. 8(a) and (c), when temperature is between 20.0 and 350.0 ℃, the weight loss assigned to bound water removal increases from 3.89% to 4.86% after doping Mn8Ni2O x catalyst with Ce, and the temperature peaking point of DTG curves (representing fastest removal rate) decreased from 219.0 ℃ to 52.0 ℃, indicating that the dehydration ability of the catalyst was drastically enhanced. In the temperature range of 350.0–800.0 ℃, although the peaking temperature of hydroxylation and lattice oxygen removal increases from 578.0 ℃ to 657.0 ℃ after Ce doping, the corresponding weight loss of lattice oxygen removed is also increased from 5.73% to 6.37%, indicating that Ce doping can benefit to increase the content of lattice oxygen species released. Besides, by comparing Fig. 8(a) and(b), we can see that the dehydration amount of the Mn8Ni2O x catalyst has increased after the water resistance test, indicating that a considerable part of the catalyst's surface sites is occupied by water vapor adsorption when reacting under humid atmosphere. While from Fig. 8(c) and (d), it is found that the dehydration amount of the Mn8Ni2CeO x catalyst decreased by 0.23%, indicating that the Ce introduction can effectively inhibit H2O adsorption on the catalyst surface. In the high-temperature region, the weight loss assigned to hydroxyl and lattice oxygen removal of the Mn8Ni2O x catalyst does not change much after the water resistance test, while that of the Mn8Ni2CeO x catalyst decreased from 6.37% to 3.80%. This suggests that the lattice oxygen species of Mn8Ni2CeO x catalyst was consumed during the water resistance test, and the addition of Ce can facilitate lattice oxygen mobility to the catalyst surface and participates in the reaction, thus the Mn8Ni2CeO x catalyst can also maintain good activity in the humid reaction atmosphere and exhibits significantly improved hydrothermal stability. Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (FTIR) was conducted to verify the evolution of surface chemical groups. Fig. 9 presents transmission FTIR spectra of Mn8Ni2CeO x and Mn8Ni2O x catalysts before/after the water resistance test. The absorption peaks at 3200–3600 cm−1 and 1632 cm−1 belong to the symmetric stretching vibration and bending vibration of the OH bond [39], the absorption peak at 2359 cm−1 corresponds to the antisymmetric stretching vibration of the -CO bond in CO2, while the absorption peak at 519–623 cm−1 is attributed to the vibrational peak of the Me-O (Ce-O, Mn-O, etc.) bond [40]. As shown in Fig. 9, the OH vibration peak at 3200–3600 cm−1 of the Mn8Ni2CeO x catalyst is clearly enhanced after the water resistance test compared to the weakened OH vibration peak of Mn8Ni2O x , which demonstrates that the generation of more abundant surface hydroxyl groups on the Mn8Ni2CeO x surface. Hanse and Wolverton[41] revealed via DFT calculation that H2O can adsorb on the surface VO of CeO2 and form surface hydroxyls, which creates the thermodynamically favored pathway for vacancy diffusion from the bulk to the surface, thus being beneficial for utilizing lattice oxygen. Zhang et al. [42] demonstrated that H2O adsorbed on VO of CeO2 can generate surface hydroxyl groups and promote O2 dissociation and formation of active oxygen, thus being conducive to toluene oxidation. Hence, the enhanced water resistance of Mn8Ni2CeO x in our work can be reasonably ascribed to the Ce modification-induced VO and formation of surface hydroxyl groups. Besides, the Me-O vibration peak of Mn8Ni2CeO x catalyst remained unchanged compared to the weakened Me-O vibration peak of Mn8Ni2O x , indicating that the structural stability is also enhanced by Ce doping [40]. H2 temperature-programmed reduction Fig. 10 gives the H2-TPR profiles of the prepared Mn8Ni2Ce a O x (a = 0–1.5) catalysts. The reduction peak around 238.0–327.0 ℃ corresponds to the reduction of MnO2/Mn2O3 to Mn3O4, while the reduction peak around 327.0–420.0 ℃ corresponds to the reduction of Mn3O4 to MnO [43]. The other peak around 420.0–560.0 ℃ is commonly to be related reduction of lattice oxygen [44]. For the Mn8Ni2Ce a O x catalyst, with increasing Ce content, the corresponding temperatures of each reduction peaks shift to low-temperature ranges and then go back to high temperatures. Mn8Ni2CeO x (a = 1) catalyst exhibits the greatest extent of such low-temperature peak shifting, i.e., the lowest reduction temperatures. This proves that proper doping of Ce can substantially improve the overall redox ability and oxygen storage/release capability of Mn8Ni2CeO x catalyst, which could be induced by the enrichment of surface adsorbed oxygen species or the facilitated mobility of oxygen species [43,44]. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy The chemical states of surface elements before/after Ce doping were analyzed by XPS, and the obtained spectra were shown in Fig. 11 along with quantitative results listed in Table 5 . Fig. 11(a) shows the overall scanning spectra of both Mn8Ni2O x and Mn8Ni2CeO x catalysts, in which the appearance of a new Ce peak confirms the successful doping of Ce. Mn 2p3/2 spectra, which is shown in Fig. 11(b), is further fitted into three peaks of 640.6 eV, 641.6 eV and 642.9 eV corresponding to Mn2+, Mn3+ and Mn4+, respectively [45]. After Ce doping, the content of Mn3+ increased significantly (see Table 5, 52.60% for Mn8Ni2CeO x and 17.20% for Mn8Ni2O x ). Zhao et al. [21] reported that for Ce-Mn composite oxides the interaction of Mn3+-O is weaker than that of Mn4+-O, which is conducive to the mobility of active oxygen species and thereby improves the catalytic performance. In addition, it is quite clear that the Mn3+ peak of Mn8Ni2CeO x catalyst shifts to lower binding energy ranges compared to that of Mn8Ni2O x , indicating a certain interaction between Ce and Mn [21]. According to previous studies [46], the Ce-Mn interaction is conducive to the feasible generation of oxygen vacancies, enhanced lattice migration as well as abundant surface active oxygen through the facilitated redox couple (Ce4+/Ce3+ ↔ Mn4+/Mn3+/Mn2+). Hence, such interactions have also been widely recognized beneficial for fimproving the low-temperature redox capacity as well as the catalytic activity [47,48]. Fig. 11(c) presents the Ce 3d spectra, which can be decomposed into two major spin-orbital sets as 3d5/2 (marked by V) and 3d3/2 (marked by U) respectively. The peaks of V, V'' and V''' are assigned to Ce4+ 3d5/2, while the three peaks of U, U'' and U''' can be attributed to Ce4+ 3d3/2, whereas V' and U' are assigned to surface Ce3+ species [49]. The existence of Ce3+ species is generally associated with the formation of oxygen vacancies (VO), which is well reported to improve the generation of active oxygen species and promotion of their migration from the bulk phase, thus resulting in improved catalytic oxidation performance of toluene [21,47,50,51]. Fig. 11(d) presents the O 1 s spectra, which can be decomposed into 3 peaks located around 528.5 eV, 530.9 eV and 532.2 eV, respectively. The strong peak at 528.5 eV is assigned to lattice oxygen O2 − (denoted as Oα), while the two shoulder peaks (530.6 eV −532.5 eV) with higher binding energy correspond to active surface adsorbed oxygen species such as O2 −, O −, OH− (denoted as Oβ) [52]. The Oβ/(Oα+Oβ) molar ratios of Mn8Ni2CeO x and Mn8Ni2O x are 42.00% and 31.00%, respectively. These results reveal that the Ce doping also leads to increased active surface adsorbed oxygen species [21], which could be related to the existence of surface oxygen defects, oxygen vacancies or unsaturation chemical bonds on the catalyst's surface [53]. In-situ FITR characterizations (1) Toluene adsorption Fig. 12 shows the in-situ FTIR spectra of toluene adsorption process over Mn8Ni2O x and Mn8Ni2CeO x catalysts as a function of time at 180.0 ℃. The major peak attributions are as follows: the strongest absorption peaks at 1418 and 1540 cm−1 are attributed to the symmetric/asymmetric stretching vibration of the C=O bond, indicating the formation of benzoate [54]; the peak at 1175 cm−1 is assigned to the CO stretching vibration, indicating the formation of Benzyl alcohol species [55]; the peaks around 1594 cm−1 are attributed to out-of-plane and in-plane vibrations of aromatic rings; the double peak around 2340 cm−1 corresponds to CO2; while the peak at 3060 cm−1 belongs to the stretching vibration of phenyl CH of aromatic rings [56]. From Fig. 12, it can be seen that toluene adsorption reaches saturation on Mn8Ni2O x in about 20 min, while for Mn8Ni2CeO x the adsorption saturates in about 5 min, which suggests better adsorption capability of Mn8Ni2CeO x catalyst. Noticing the enhancement of the absorption peaks at 3060, 1145, 1175, 1418, and 1540 cm−1, we can propose that some of the toluene still exists in the form of benzene rings during the adsorption process, while the rest is converted into intermediate products such as benzoate and benzyl alcohol. The stronger band intensity of on Mn8Ni2CeO x suggests the more easy-going oxidation of toluene to these intermediate products after Ce doping. This phenomenon can be explained as that surface active oxygen plays a crucial role in the conversion of toluene to intermediates in the absence of O2 [56] and Ce introduction increases active surface adsorbed oxygen species content as well as promotes active oxygen species mobility, which is in good consistency with the XPS results. (2) Toluene oxidation Fig. 13 shows the in-situ FTIR spectra toluene oxidation process over Mn8Ni2O x and Mn8Ni2CeO x catalysts by feeding O2 upon adsorption saturation while simultaneously ramping the reaction temperature. The major peak attributions are quite similar as mentioned above. For Mn8Ni2CeO x , the benzyl alcohol peak at 1175 cm−1 disappeared while the benzoate peaks at 1418 and 1594 cm−1 are slightly increased, indicating benzyl alcohol can be completely oxidized to benzoate over Mn8Ni2CeO x at 180.0 ℃. With the temperature increasing, the benzoate peaks became smaller while the CO2 peak increased correspondingly, indicating that benzoate is gradually oxidized to CO2. At 220.0 ℃ close to its T90 (218.0 ℃), the benzoate peak on the Mn8Ni2CeO x catalyst is greatly reduced with largely increased CO2 peak, validating that the majority of benzoate has been completely oxidized; For Mn8Ni2O x , after feeding O2 at 180.0 ℃, the benzyl alcohol peak can still be observed, while the peak intensity of benzoate and CO2 does not change significantly, indicating relatively slower conversion of benzyl alcohol to benzoate. Besides, higher temperature above 240.0 ℃ is required to achieve large consumption of benzoate peaks and CO2 peaks growth, suggesting insufficient ability for the further deep oxidation of benzoate species over Mn8Ni2O x . These results clear evidence that the addition of Ce can also effectively accelerate the deep oxidation of benzyl alcohol and benzoate by efficiently utilizing active oxygen species, therefore rendering activity advantages to Mn8Ni2CeO x catalyst. Brief discussions regarding the reaction mechanism Langmuir-Hinshelwood (L-H), Eley-Rideal (E-R) and Mars-van Krevelen (MvK) are proved to be three typical reaction kinetic models for the catalytic oxidation mechanism of VOCs. For mixed oxides catalysts, the most commonly explained mechanism is the MvK model [57,58] due to the abundance of active oxygen species on their surfaces [59,60]. Combining the above activity and characterization results, a similar MvK process can be proposed for the toluene oxidation over Mn8Ni2CeO x catalyst (Fig. 14 ) as follows: First, toluene is dehydrogenated and activated to benzyl alcohol; then benzyl alcohol reacts with surface active oxygen to form benzoate species; afterward, the consumed surface active oxygen can be replenished via either gaseous O2 dissociation or the migration of lattice oxygen to the catalyst's surface; eventually, benzoate is oxidized to the final product CO2 and H2O [38]. The reaction rate is likely to be limited by the deep oxidation of reaction intermediates [21]. On one hand, Ce introduction leads to efficient utilization of active oxygen species by forming strong Ce-Mn interactions, generating more oxygen vacancies, facilitating lattice oxygen mobility and increasing surface active oxygen content, therefore effectively accelerating the deep oxidation of benzyl alcohol/benzoate intermediates, and thus rendering activity advantages to Mn8Ni2CeO x catalyst. On the other hand, Ce doping can effectively maintain the catalyst's structural stability while simultaneously inhibiting H2O adsorption on the catalyst surface under humid atmosphere, thus being conducive to the outstanding durability and water resistance ability of Mn8Ni2CeO x catalyst. Conclusion In this work, a series of Mn8Ni2Ce a O x composite oxide catalysts (a = 0.25–1.5) were synthesized by co-precipitation method using catalytic toluene combustion as model reaction. Mn8Ni2CeO x (a = 1) proves to possess the most outstanding catalytic performance (T50 and T90 of 213.3 ℃ and 219.6 ℃, respectively) as well as significantly outstanding water resistance ability (steady 92.00% toluene conversion under the reaction atmosphere containing 5 vol.% H2O), which could serve as a promising candidate for practical applications. Such catalytic advantages can be attributed to two aspects based on various characterizations. First of all, Ce introduction leads to efficient utilization of active oxygen species in multiple ways such as establishing strong Ce-Mn interactions, generating more oxygen vacancies, facilitating lattice oxygen mobility as well as increasing the surface-active oxygen content. Hence, the deep oxidation of benzyl alcohol/benzoate intermediates can be effectively accelerated over Mn8Ni2CeO x catalyst. Secondly, Ce doping also helps to stabilize the catalyst's structure and inhibits H2O adsorption on the catalyst surface under humid atmosphere concurrently, therefore allowing Mn8Ni2Ce a O x (a = 1) to present outstanding durability and water resistance ability. coredata.dc:description: A series of metal oxides Mn8Ni2Ce a O x (a = 0–1.5) catalysts were prepared by hydrothermal co-precipitation to investigate the effect of Ce doping on manganese-based oxides for toluene catalytic combustion reaction. Activity evaluations show that Mn8Ni2CeO x (a = 1) catalyst exhibits highly efficient toluene oxidation activity and high yield to CO2 production. Durability tests reveal that it has remarkably superior water resistance ability and promising potential for practical application. Various characterizations were conducted to explore possible structure-activity correlations. Results show that Ce introduction could construct the strong Ce-Mn interactions, generate more oxygen vacancies, facilitate lattice oxygen mobility, and increase the content of surface active oxygen. These changes efficiently utilize active oxygen species and accelerate the deep oxidation of benzyl alcohol/benzoate intermediates, therefore render activity advantages. Otherwise, Ce doping can effectively maintain the catalyst's structural stability while simultaneously inhibiting H2O adsorption on the catalyst surface under humid atmosphere, thus being conducive to the outstanding durability and water resistance ability.
coredata.dc:title: Promoting effect of Ce doping on catalytic performance and water resistance ability for toluene catalytic combustion over the cheap and efficient Mn8Ni2Ce a O x catalysts
